ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Discussion posts on readings, videos to watch on our time including movies etc.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great course to delve into global citizenship and migration law from a historical perspective.
Deep understanding of the law behind the South Asian diaspora.

I gained a lot of experience working with legal histories in this class, connecting case law and general legislation to migrations and racial formations. This class also gave an in-depth understanding of labor histories and an expansive perspective on how British colonization changed racial dynamics across the world.

This course was an incredible opportunity to review primary resources especially legal history resources something that is not very common in history classes. It also played a lot with different mediums of creating history including contemporary music, rap, documentaries, and even art.
This course introduced me to the history of South Asian migration patterns and its interconnectedness with empire and the legacy of slavery.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The wide range of geographies and time periods covered in this course allowed for a richer understanding of how South Asian migration intersected with questions of law, citizenship, colonialism, and decolonization, and the selections of readings covering books from history, anthropology, sociology, and fiction, as well as primary material provided a great basis for discussion.

In the beginning of the semester the readings were quite dense and overwhelming, so I really appreciated when the weekly readings were broken up, and students were allowed to pick one or two to focus on. I enjoyed how this led to small group discussions and presentations during class. This was a great opportunity to truly understand and analyze one reading in depth, while also gaining broad information about the other readings. While I appreciated how Professor De cut down and adjusted the readings to be flexible in this semester, at times it was frustrating to have the readings so much in flux, making it difficult to get ahead on the readings, since the syllabus would be changed on almost a weekly basis. Just a little advance notice on reading changes would be appreciated!

Strengths --> Excellent selection of readings, great in class discussions, and overall fantastic syllabus.
Weakness --> sometimes the readings were a bit much.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor De was incredibly lenient with student deadlines and very reflective of changing workload depending on the situation in the world both politically and covid wise. This really helped students engage better in and outside of the classroom with the materials.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Highly recommend to students interested in legal and/or South Asian history.
Yes! Especially for anyone interested in migration law and South Asia

For students looking to learn about South Asian diasporas, or diasporic history in general, this class is ideal. A little background knowledge in South Asian history would definitely be beneficial before taking this class. I thought it was good balance between critical race theory, history, and legal studies while still grounded in specific cases and experiences.
Yes. Professor De is an incredible incredible instructor and you will learn a ton from the in class discussions!
Yes! It is important for everyone and Professor De is fantastic!
